Notes: Both genera have nectaries in all DF species
Dioica, nectário presente nas flores masculinas e femininas. Silva, O. & Cordeiro, I. Flora do Brasil 2020

Flores masc. e fem. produzem nectar, a espécie é trióica (plantas masc., plantas fem., e plantas monóicas) - ver paper guildas de abelhas que visitam essa sp., Apis mell., Scaptotrigona depilis e Tetragonisca angostula foram as que mais visitaram

Micos se alimentam do nectar (Passos & Kim 1999);  Mabea therefore seems to be one of the very few genera of flowering plants that shows both a chiropterophilous and an entomophilous syndrome in different species within the same genus. Male flowere of M. fistulifera visited by Apis mell., Trigona spinipes, T. hyalinata and Partomona cupira to remove pollen; flowers produce abundant pollen and nectar

Resina, cavidades secretoras nas flores no gênero (Freitas, M.F. Myrsine in Flora do Brasil 2020); M. parvifolia (a Restinga species) is rarely visited by Trigona spinepes attracted by large amounts of pollen, visits only male plants, the species is exclusively wind-pollinated
Nectar is the reward (Oliveira et al. 2000)
Doecious species, only male flowers have significant nectar;

Espécie mais visitada pelas abelhas (29 espécies, com destaque para Trigona spinipes, Apis mellifera e registro de Tetragonisca angostula) em estudo no Paraná (3 propriedades rurais). R. articus (Estonia) produz nectar (Karp et al. 2004), assim como R. idaeus, R. pubescens e R. allegheniensis (Whitney 1984).
Reward is pollen (Martins & Batalha 1988); oil flower
Esser 2012 does not mention nectaries on the floral bracts, such as occur in Mabea
Odourless, mostly visited by Diptera in SE Brazil, only 3% visits by Hymenoptera; pollinated by Trigona spp. in Costa Rica that collect "large amounts of pollen in their pollen baskets"
